elements.content: A new non-centrosymmetric strontium–organic framework material (CAUMOF-8) with one-dimensional nanochannels has been synthesized under solvothermal conditions. CAUMOF-8 exhibits a helical channel structure consisting of strontium oxide polyhedra and a 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate linker. The channels run along the c-axis and are approximately 12 Å in diameter. The amount of void space for the material can be calculated to be ca. 47% from the single-crystal structure. The structure exhibits a very high thermal stability up to 520 °C. Powder second-harmonic generating (SHG) measurements on CAUMOF-8 revealed SHG efficiency of 20 times that of α-SiO2 and the material is phase-matchable (Type 1).
elements.clean_text: A new non-centrosymmetric strontium-organic framework material (CAUMOF-8) with one-dimensional nanochannels has been synthesized under solvothermal conditions. CAUMOF-8 exhibits a helical channel structure consisting of strontium oxide polyhedra and a 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate linker. The channels run along the c-axis and are approximately 12 Å in diameter. The amount of void space for the material can be calculated to be ca. 47% from the single-crystal structure. The structure exhibits a very high thermal stability up to 520 °C. Powder second-harmonic generating (SHG) measurements on CAUMOF-8 revealed SHG efficiency of 20 times that of α-SiO2 and the material is phase-matchable (Type 1).

elements.content:
A new non-centrosymmetric strontium−organic framework material with one-dimensional nanochannels and high thermal stability has been synthesized under solvothermal conditions.

A great deal of efforts have been continuously made to develop novel metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) that demonstrate a wide variety of geometries and extensive applications such as gas adsorption/storage, isolation, separation, ion-exchange, sensing, and catalysis. Almost all kinds of metal cations such as main group, transition, rare-earth, lanthanide, alkali, and actinide metals have been combined with various organic linkers. It is getting much more important to discover novel multifunctional MOFs presenting both unusual structures and functional behaviors with new concepts. The reported multifunctional materials have exhibited both conventional characteristics of MOFs arising from the open structural nature and further interesting functional properties such as luminescent, magnetic, ferroelectric, and nonlinear optical properties at the same time. Although several examples of strontium–organic framework materials adopting diverse topologies and coordination environments have been reported, multifunctional tubular strontium–organic frameworks have never been observed. In addition, Sr-89 and Sr-90 comprises approximately 10% of the highly active components in the fission products of uranium. Thus, it would be very attractive to develop strontium-based framework materials for the application to the nuclear waste storage. Here we report the first multifunctional one-dimensional (1D) nanotubular strontium–organic framework, Sr2[C6H3(CO2)3(NO3)]·DMF (CAUMOF-8, Chung-Ang University Metal–Organic Framework-8) with a non-centrosymmetric crystal structure and very high thermal stability.
elements.clean_text:
A new non-centrosymmetric strontium-organic framework material with one-dimensional nanochannels and high thermal stability has been synthesized under solvothermal conditions.

A great deal of efforts have been continuously made to develop novel metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) that demonstrate a wide variety of geometries and extensive applications such as gas adsorption/storage, isolation, separation, ion-exchange, sensing, and catalysis. Almost all kinds of metal cations such as main group, transition, rare-earth, lanthanide, alkali, and actinide metals have been combined with various organic linkers. It is getting much more important to discover novel multifunctional MOFs presenting both unusual structures and functional behaviors with new concepts. The reported multifunctional materials have exhibited both conventional characteristics of MOFs arising from the open structural nature and further interesting functional properties such as luminescent, magnetic, ferroelectric, and nonlinear optical properties at the same time. Although several examples of strontium-organic framework materials adopting diverse topologies and coordination environments have been reported, multifunctional tubular strontium-organic frameworks have never been observed. In addition, Sr-89 and Sr-90 comprises approximately 10% of the highly active components in the fission products of uranium. Thus, it would be very attractive to develop strontium-based framework materials for the application to the nuclear waste storage. Here we report the first multifunctional one-dimensional (1D) nanotubular strontium-organic framework, Sr2[C6H3(CO2)3(NO3)]⋅DMF (CAUMOF-8, Chung-Ang University Metal-Organic Framework-8) with a non-centrosymmetric crystal structure and very high thermal stability.

elements.content: CAUMOF-8 was synthesized solvothermally by combining N(CH3)4Cl, Sr(NO3)2, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC), HNO3, and HCON(CH3)2 in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 180 °C for 3 days. Several attempts have been made to synthesize a series of new Sr-organic materials by adding various alkyl ammonium halides such as (C n H2n+1)4NX (n = 1–3; X = F or Cl) as structure directing agents. However, none of these are incorporated into the structure, but the products always turned out to be CAUMOF-8. Powder X-ray diffraction experiments on the isolated samples at different times at 180 °C indicate that the crystallization of CAUMOF-8 is relatively fast (see ). Initially, the staring material Sr(NO3)2 and a small amount of N(CH3)4(NO3) are observed from 5 to 30 min of heating. The diffraction peaks for Sr(NO3)2 disappeared as time goes on and those for N(CH3)4(NO3) grew up until 7 h of heating. A signal corresponding to the (100) Bragg reflection (2θ ≈ 5.86°) for CAUMOF-8 was first observed after about 8 h of heating and then the peak as well as other reflections increased in intensity over the next 4 h, at which point the intensity remained constant during the remainder of the experiment.
elements.clean_text: CAUMOF-8 was synthesized solvothermally by combining N(CH3)4Cl, Sr(NO3)2, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC), HNO3, and HCON(CH3)2 in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 180 °C for 3 days. Several attempts have been made to synthesize a series of new Sr-organic materials by adding various alkyl ammonium halides such as (C n H2n+1)4NX (n = 1-3; X = F or Cl) as structure directing agents. However, none of these are incorporated into the structure, but the products always turned out to be CAUMOF-8. Powder X-ray diffraction experiments on the isolated samples at different times at 180 °C indicate that the crystallization of CAUMOF-8 is relatively fast (see ). Initially, the staring material Sr(NO3)2 and a small amount of N(CH3)4(NO3) are observed from 5 to 30 min of heating. The diffraction peaks for Sr(NO3)2 disappeared as time goes on and those for N(CH3)4(NO3) grew up until 7 h of heating. A signal corresponding to the (100) Bragg reflection (2θ ~ 5.86°) for CAUMOF-8 was first observed after about 8 h of heating and then the peak as well as other reflections increased in intensity over the next 4 h, at which point the intensity remained constant during the remainder of the experiment.

elements.content: Ball-and stick and space filling models of CAUMOF-8 representing helical nanotubular channels in (a) the ab-plane and (b) the ac-plane, respectively (yellow, Sr; gray, C; blue, N; red, O).
elements.clean_text: 1  Ball-and stick and space filling models of CAUMOF-8 representing helical nanotubular channels in (a) the ab-plane and (b) the ac-plane, respectively (yellow, Sr; gray, C; blue, N; red, O).

elements.content: CAUMOF-8 crystallizes as colorless rod-shaped crystals. The structure of CAUMOF-8 is composed of infinite channels containing the SrO8, SrO9, NO3, and the organic BTC group that are connected through oxygen atoms (see Figure a). There are two unique Sr2+ cations; Sr(1)2+ is bonded to nine oxygen atoms, whereas Sr(2)2+ is coordinated by eight oxygen atoms. The Sr2+–O bond lengths range from 2.542(6) to 2.94(3) Å. These values are consistent with those of previously reported materials. Bond valence calculations on CAUMOF-8 resulted in values of 1.84–2.15 for Sr2+ cations. One of the most interesting structural features of CAUMOF-8 is that the SrO8 and SrO9 polyhedra share faces and form infinite helical chains running along the [001] direction (see Figure b). The helical chains are further linked by the SrO9, BTC linkers, and NO3 groups through oxygen atoms to form an unprecedented nanotubular channel structure. Although the coordinated NO3 groups are disordered, they point inward within the channels. As seen in Figure a, CAUMOF-8 exhibits small three-membered rings (3-MR) and large eighteen-membered rings (18-MR) along the [001] direction. The dimension of the large ring channels running down the c-axis is approximately 15.1 Å (face to face) × 17.3 Å (corner to corner) excluding the coordinated NO3 groups. Taking into account the atomic radii of the constituent atoms, the diameter of the largest sphere that will fit into the channels is ca. 12 Å. The dimensions of the ring channels shrink to 9.0 Å × 10.2 Å, once the NO3 groups are added. CAUMOF-8 also has both 6-MR’s and 8-MR’s along the [100] and [010] directions (see ). There are some disordered DMF molecules residing within the channels, but these are very poorly resolved by the X-ray diffraction experiment. However, we were able to analyze the amount of uncoordinated DMF molecules through the thermal and elemental analyses.
elements.clean_text: CAUMOF-8 crystallizes as colorless rod-shaped crystals. The structure of CAUMOF-8 is composed of infinite channels containing the SrO8, SrO9, NO3, and the organic BTC group that are connected through oxygen atoms (see Figure a). There are two unique Sr2+ cations; Sr(1)2+ is bonded to nine oxygen atoms, whereas Sr(2)2+ is coordinated by eight oxygen atoms. The Sr2+-O bond lengths range from 2.542(6) to 2.94(3) Å. These values are consistent with those of previously reported materials. Bond valence calculations on CAUMOF-8 resulted in values of 1.84-2.15 for Sr2+ cations. One of the most interesting structural features of CAUMOF-8 is that the SrO8 and SrO9 polyhedra share faces and form infinite helical chains running along the [001] direction (see Figure b). The helical chains are further linked by the SrO9, BTC linkers, and NO3 groups through oxygen atoms to form an unprecedented nanotubular channel structure. Although the coordinated NO3 groups are disordered, they point inward within the channels. As seen in Figure a, CAUMOF-8 exhibits small three-membered rings (3-MR) and large eighteen-membered rings (18-MR) along the [001] direction. The dimension of the large ring channels running down the c-axis is approximately 15.1 Å (face to face) × 17.3 Å (corner to corner) excluding the coordinated NO3 groups. Taking into account the atomic radii of the constituent atoms, the diameter of the largest sphere that will fit into the channels is ca. 12 Å. The dimensions of the ring channels shrink to 9.0 Å × 10.2 Å, once the NO3 groups are added. CAUMOF-8 also has both 6-MR's and 8-MR's along the [100] and [010] directions (see ). There are some disordered DMF molecules residing within the channels, but these are very poorly resolved by the X-ray diffraction experiment. However, we were able to analyze the amount of uncoordinated DMF molecules through the thermal and elemental analyses.

elements.content: The amount of void space can be calculated by removing all the occluded solvent molecules and using the CALC SOLV command in PLATON. For CAUMOF-8, the amount of void space is 47%, whereas the value for the zeolite cloverite is 60%. The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the polycrystalline sample of CAUMOF-8 is in excellent agreement with the calculated pattern based on the single-crystal model (see ).
elements.clean_text: The amount of void space can be calculated by removing all the occluded solvent molecules and using the CALC SOLV command in PLATON. For CAUMOF-8, the amount of void space is 47%, whereas the value for the zeolite cloverite is 60%. The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the polycrystalline sample of CAUMOF-8 is in excellent agreement with the calculated pattern based on the single-crystal model (see ).

elements.content: Adsorption isotherms of H2 (◼, 77 K), CO2 (red circles, 196 K), and N2 (blue triangles, 77 K) on CAUMOF-8.
elements.clean_text: 2  Adsorption isotherms of H2 (◼, 77 K), CO2 (red circles, 196 K), and N2 (blue triangles, 77 K) on CAUMOF-8.

elements.content: The stable framework geometry and large effective pore diameter of the CAUMOF-8 led us to monitor some gas adsorption into the channels. The N2 adsorption isotherm for CAUMOF-8 at 77 K exhibits features resulting from a microporous material, that is, a type I isotherm (Figure ). As seen in the Figure , the adsorption capacity of CAUMOF-8 for CO2 at 195 K is similar to that of N2. Analysis of the experimental data estimated by the Langmuir surface area on the basis of the N2 adsorption yields 480 m2/g. The relative small surface area of the CAUMOF-8 as an MOF may be attributable to the tubular nature of the structure: the effective size of the tubular channel is reduced due to the offset stacking of the phenyl ring of the BTC ligand moiety. Approximate pore diameters can be calculated to be 8–14 Å, which is in good agreement with the estimation from the single-crystal data (see ).
elements.clean_text: The stable framework geometry and large effective pore diameter of the CAUMOF-8 led us to monitor some gas adsorption into the channels. The N2 adsorption isotherm for CAUMOF-8 at 77 K exhibits features resulting from a microporous material, that is, a type I isotherm (Figure ). As seen in the Figure , the adsorption capacity of CAUMOF-8 for CO2 at 195 K is similar to that of N2. Analysis of the experimental data estimated by the Langmuir surface area on the basis of the N2 adsorption yields 480 m2/g. The relative small surface area of the CAUMOF-8 as an MOF may be attributable to the tubular nature of the structure: the effective size of the tubular channel is reduced due to the offset stacking of the phenyl ring of the BTC ligand moiety. Approximate pore diameters can be calculated to be 8-14 Å, which is in good agreement with the estimation from the single-crystal data (see ).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis on the CAUMOF-8 shows a weight loss of 12.5% between room temperature and 520 °C, which is attributable to the loss of occluded DMF molecules (see Figure a). The framework starts decomposing after 520 °C and the material collapses to SrCO3. The thermal stability of the framework for CAUMOF-8 was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction. As can be seen in the Figure b, no substantial changes in the peak intensities are observed in the powder XRD patterns up to 500 °C. The XRD pattern obtained at 600 °C is identified as SrCO3. It is worth noting that the framework of CAUMOF-8 is quite thermally stable as an MOF. As found in the several reported thermally stable MOFs, the high thermal stability of CAUMOF-8 is ascribed to the flexibility of the linker molecules, the coordinatively linked interpenetration, and highly symmetric structural environment. CO2 is lost at around 750 °C leaving SrO.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis on the CAUMOF-8 shows a weight loss of 12.5% between room temperature and 520 °C, which is attributable to the loss of occluded DMF molecules (see Figure a). The framework starts decomposing after 520 °C and the material collapses to SrCO3. The thermal stability of the framework for CAUMOF-8 was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction. As can be seen in the Figure b, no substantial changes in the peak intensities are observed in the powder XRD patterns up to 500 °C. The XRD pattern obtained at 600 °C is identified as SrCO3. It is worth noting that the framework of CAUMOF-8 is quite thermally stable as an MOF. As found in the several reported thermally stable MOFs, the high thermal stability of CAUMOF-8 is ascribed to the flexibility of the linker molecules, the coordinatively linked interpenetration, and highly symmetric structural environment. CO2 is lost at around 750 °C leaving SrO.

elements.content: (a) TGA diagram and (b) powder X-ray diffraction patterns at different temperatures for CAUMOF-8. Note no substantial changes in the peak position and intensity are observed up to 500 °C.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) TGA diagram and (b) powder X-ray diffraction patterns at different temperatures for CAUMOF-8. Note no substantial changes in the peak position and intensity are observed up to 500 °C.

elements.content: Since CAUMOF-8 crystallizes in a non-centrosymmetric space group, we investigated its nonlinear optical properties. Powder second-harmonic generation (SHG) measurements, using 1064 nm radiation, indicated that CAUMOF-8 has a SHG efficiency of approximately 20 times that of α-SiO2. By sieving CAUMOF-8 powder into various particle sizes, ranging from 20–150 μm, and measuring the SHG as a function of particle size, we were able to determine that the material was type 1 phase-matchable (see Figure ). On the basis of the SHG efficiency and phase-matching measurements, CAUMOF-8 falls into the class B category of SHG materials, as defined by Kurtz and Perry. Once the SHG efficiency and the phase-matching capability of a material are known, the bulk SHG efficiency, <d eff>exp, can be estimated. For CAUMOF-8, <d eff>exp is approximately 3.0 pm V–1. The observation of this SHG is attributable to the helical arrangement of the chains within the channel.
elements.clean_text: Since CAUMOF-8 crystallizes in a non-centrosymmetric space group, we investigated its nonlinear optical properties. Powder second-harmonic generation (SHG) measurements, using 1064 nm radiation, indicated that CAUMOF-8 has a SHG efficiency of approximately 20 times that of α-SiO2. By sieving CAUMOF-8 powder into various particle sizes, ranging from 20-150 μm, and measuring the SHG as a function of particle size, we were able to determine that the material was type 1 phase-matchable (see Figure ). On the basis of the SHG efficiency and phase-matching measurements, CAUMOF-8 falls into the class B category of SHG materials, as defined by Kurtz and Perry. Once the SHG efficiency and the phase-matching capability of a material are known, the bulk SHG efficiency, <d eff>exp, can be estimated. For CAUMOF-8, <d eff>exp is approximately 3.0 pm V-1. The observation of this SHG is attributable to the helical arrangement of the chains within the channel.

elements.content: Phase matching curve (type 1) for CAUMOF-8. The curve is to guide the eye and is not a fit to the data.
elements.clean_text: 4  Phase matching curve (type 1) for CAUMOF-8. The curve is to guide the eye and is not a fit to the data.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized a novel multifunctional non-centrosymmetric strontium–organic framework material with high thermal stability. We are in the process of extending the organic linkers and some intercalation experiments using a variety of guest molecules.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized a novel multifunctional non-centrosymmetric strontium-organic framework material with high thermal stability. We are in the process of extending the organic linkers and some intercalation experiments using a variety of guest molecules.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format, experimental and calculated powder XRD patterns, pore size distribution plot, powder XRD patterns showing the crystallization process, crystallographic description, and wire models for CAUMOF-8. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format, experimental and calculated powder XRD patterns, pore size distribution plot, powder XRD patterns showing the crystallization process, crystallographic description, and wire models for CAUMOF-8. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: CAUMOF-8 was synthesized by combining N(CH3)4Cl (0.219 g, 2.00 × 10–3 mol), Sr(NO3)2 (0.539 g, 2.00 × 10–3 mol), 1,3,5-C6H3(CO2H)3 (0.210 g, 1.00 × 10–3 mol), HCON(CH3)2 (10 mL), and HNO3 (0.5 mL). The reaction mixture was transferred to a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was subsequently sealed and heated to 180 °C for 3 days, before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 °C h–1. The autoclave was opened and the product was recovered by filtration and washed with ethanol. Colorless rod crystals were recovered for CAUMOF-8 in 68% yield based on Sr(NO3)2. IR data: 3085, 1611, 1557, 1439, 1380, 1112, 941, 769, 721, 534, 453 cm–1. Elemental analysis. Calcd: C, 27.68; H, 2.03; N, 5.51. Exptl: C, 27.81; H, 1.95; N, 5.41.
elements.clean_text:
References

CAUMOF-8 was synthesized by combining N(CH3)4Cl (0.219 g, 2.00 × 10-3 mol), Sr(NO3)2 (0.539 g, 2.00 × 10-3 mol), 1,3,5-C6H3(CO2H)3 (0.210 g, 1.00 × 10-3 mol), HCON(CH3)2 (10 mL), and HNO3 (0.5 mL). The reaction mixture was transferred to a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was subsequently sealed and heated to 180 °C for 3 days, before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 °C h-1. The autoclave was opened and the product was recovered by filtration and washed with ethanol. Colorless rod crystals were recovered for CAUMOF-8 in 68% yield based on Sr(NO3)2. IR data: 3085, 1611, 1557, 1439, 1380, 1112, 941, 769, 721, 534, 453 cm-1. Elemental analysis. Calcd: C, 27.68; H, 2.03; N, 5.51. Exptl: C, 27.81; H, 1.95; N, 5.41.

elements.content: A colorless rod crystal of dimension 0.10 × 0.12 × 0.30 mm3 for CAUMOF-8 was used for structural determination. Data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD X-ray diffractometer at the Korea Basic Science institute at room temperature using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Crystal data: hexagonal, space group P-62c (No. 190) with a = b = 17.3726(7) Å, c = 10.0243(8) Å, V = 2620.1(3) Å3, Z = 6, ρcalc = 1.691 g cm–3, 2θmax = 58.22°, λ = 0.71073 Å, T = 298.0(2) K, total data 1325, observed data (I > 2σ(I)) = 1214, μ = 6.125 mm–1, 117 parameters, R int =0.0186, observed R(F)/R w (F)= 0.0419/0.1512 on |F 2|.
elements.clean_text: A colorless rod crystal of dimension 0.10 × 0.12 × 0.30 mm3 for CAUMOF-8 was used for structural determination. Data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD X-ray diffractometer at the Korea Basic Science institute at room temperature using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Crystal data: hexagonal, space group P-62c (No. 190) with a = b = 17.3726(7) Å, c = 10.0243(8) Å, V = 2620.1(3) Å3, Z = 6, ρcalc = 1.691 g cm-3, 2θmax = 58.22°, λ = 0.71073 Å, T = 298.0(2) K, total data 1325, observed data (I > 2σ(I)) = 1214, μ = 6.125 mm-1, 117 parameters, R int =0.0186, observed R(F)/R  w (F)= 0.0419/0.1512 on |F 2|.

cln_elements.content:
A new non-centrosymmetric strontium–organic framework material (CAUMOF-8) with one-dimensional nanochannels has been synthesized under solvothermal conditions. CAUMOF-8 exhibits a helical channel structure consisting of strontium oxide polyhedra and a 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate linker. The channels run along the c-axis and are approximately 12 Å in diameter. The amount of void space for the material can be calculated to be ca. 47% from the single-crystal structure. The structure exhibits a very high thermal stability up to 520 °C. Powder second-harmonic generating (SHG) measurements on CAUMOF-8 revealed SHG efficiency of 20 times that of α-SiO2 and the material is phase-matchable (Type 1).

Thermogravimetric analysis on the CAUMOF-8 shows a weight loss of 12.5% between room temperature and 520 °C, which is attributable to the loss of occluded DMF molecules (see Figure a). The framework starts decomposing after 520 °C and the material collapses to SrCO3. The thermal stability of the framework for CAUMOF-8 was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction. As can be seen in the Figure b, no substantial changes in the peak intensities are observed in the powder XRD patterns up to 500 °C. The XRD pattern obtained at 600 °C is identified as SrCO3. It is worth noting that the framework of CAUMOF-8 is quite thermally stable as an MOF. As found in the several reported thermally stable MOFs, the high thermal stability of CAUMOF-8 is ascribed to the flexibility of the linker molecules, the coordinatively linked interpenetration, and highly symmetric structural environment. CO2 is lost at around 750 °C leaving SrO.

A colorless rod crystal of dimension 0.10 × 0.12 × 0.30 mm3 for CAUMOF-8 was used for structural determination. Data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD X-ray diffractometer at the Korea Basic Science institute at room temperature using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Crystal data: hexagonal, space group P-62c (No. 190) with a = b = 17.3726(7) Å, c = 10.0243(8) Å, V = 2620.1(3) Å3, Z = 6, ρcalc = 1.691 g cm–3, 2θmax = 58.22°, λ = 0.71073 Å, T = 298.0(2) K, total data 1325, observed data (I > 2σ(I)) = 1214, μ = 6.125 mm–1, 117 parameters, R int =0.0186, observed R(F)/R w (F)= 0.0419/0.1512 on |F 2|.
cln_elements.clean_text:
A new non-centrosymmetric strontium-organic framework material (CAUMOF-8) with one-dimensional nanochannels has been synthesized under solvothermal conditions. CAUMOF-8 exhibits a helical channel structure consisting of strontium oxide polyhedra and a 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate linker. The channels run along the c-axis and are approximately 12 Å in diameter. The amount of void space for the material can be calculated to be ca. 47% from the single-crystal structure. The structure exhibits a very high thermal stability up to 520 °C. Powder second-harmonic generating (SHG) measurements on CAUMOF-8 revealed SHG efficiency of 20 times that of α-SiO2 and the material is phase-matchable (Type 1).

Thermogravimetric analysis on the CAUMOF-8 shows a weight loss of 12.5% between room temperature and 520 °C, which is attributable to the loss of occluded DMF molecules (see Figure a). The framework starts decomposing after 520 °C and the material collapses to SrCO3. The thermal stability of the framework for CAUMOF-8 was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction. As can be seen in the Figure b, no substantial changes in the peak intensities are observed in the powder XRD patterns up to 500 °C. The XRD pattern obtained at 600 °C is identified as SrCO3. It is worth noting that the framework of CAUMOF-8 is quite thermally stable as an MOF. As found in the several reported thermally stable MOFs, the high thermal stability of CAUMOF-8 is ascribed to the flexibility of the linker molecules, the coordinatively linked interpenetration, and highly symmetric structural environment. CO2 is lost at around 750 °C leaving SrO.

A colorless rod crystal of dimension 0.10 × 0.12 × 0.30 mm3 for CAUMOF-8 was used for structural determination. Data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD X-ray diffractometer at the Korea Basic Science institute at room temperature using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Crystal data: hexagonal, space group P-62c (No. 190) with a = b = 17.3726(7) Å, c = 10.0243(8) Å, V = 2620.1(3) Å3, Z = 6, ρcalc = 1.691 g cm-3, 2θmax = 58.22°, λ = 0.71073 Å, T = 298.0(2) K, total data 1325, observed data (I > 2σ(I)) = 1214, μ = 6.125 mm-1, 117 parameters, R int =0.0186, observed R(F)/R  w (F)= 0.0419/0.1512 on |F 2|.

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules

metadata.title: Sr2[C6H3(CO2)3(NO3)]·DMF: One-Dimensional Nano-Channel in a New Non-Centrosymmetric Strontium–Organic Framework with High Thermal Stability
